001package com.technototes.library.util;
002
003import java.util.HashMap;
004import java.util.Map;
005
006/**
007 * This is a functional interface, when 'accept' is invoked, will only invoke the 'consume' method
008 * when a different value is provided. It basically removed duplicates.
009 * <p>
010 * TODO: This seems like the HashMap is completely unnecessary. Maybe I'm not following the java
011 * TODO: object model, but I don't see how map ever has more than a single value in it...
012 *
013 * @param <T> The type of the value to be accepted/consumed
014 */
015@FunctionalInterface
016public interface SmartConsumer<T> {
017    /**
018     * The map of values that have been consumed.
019     */
020    Map<SmartConsumer<?>, Object> map = new HashMap<>();
021
022    /**
023     * The 'consume' function
024     */
025    void consume(T t);
026
027    /** The public interface for a SmartConsumer: accept should be invoked, not consume :)
028     *
029     * @param t The value being consumed/accepted
030     * @return
031     */
032    default SmartConsumer<T> accept(T t) {
033        if (!t.equals(getLast())) {
034            consume(t);
035            map.put(this, t);
036        }
037        return this;
038    }
039
040    default T getLast() {
041        return (T) map.get(this);
042    }
043
044    static void reset() {
045        map.clear();
046    }
047}
